_**Star vs. the Forces of Evil**_ is an American
[animated](/wiki/Animated_series "Animated series") [television
series](/wiki/Television_series "Television series") created by Daron Nefcy
and developed by Jordana Arkin and [Dave Wasson](/wiki/Dave_Wasson "Dave
Wasson"), which airs on [Disney XD](/wiki/Disney_XD "Disney XD").[1] The first
Disney XD series created by a woman, and the third overall for [Disney
Television Animation](/wiki/Disney_Television_Animation "Disney Television
Animation") (following _[Pepper Ann](/wiki/Pepper_Ann "Pepper Ann")_ and _[Doc
McStuffins](/wiki/Doc_McStuffins "Doc McStuffins")_), it follows the
adventures of Star Butterfly (voiced by [Eden Sher](/wiki/Eden_Sher "Eden
Sher")), the turbulent young heir to the royal throne in the dimension of
Mewni, who is sent to Earth so she can complete her education and learn to be
a worthy princess, and Marco Diaz ([Adam McArthur](/wiki/Adam_McArthur "Adam
McArthur")), a human teenager who becomes her roommate and best friend, as
they live their daily lives, and go on adventures in other dimensions.[2][3]

_Star vs. the Forces of Evil_ typically follows a format of two 11-minutes
long independent "segments" per episode, with individual writing and directing
credits for each, although it occasionally opts for a single, 22-minutes long
story instead. The first episode aired on January 18, 2015 on [Disney
Channel](/wiki/Disney_Channel "Disney Channel") as a special preview, becoming
the most-watched animated series debut in Disney XD’s history; the first
season subsequently officially premiered on Disney XD on March 30, 2015.[4][1]
The third season started on July 15, 2017 and concluded on April 7, 2018.[5]
On February 28, 2017, the series was officially renewed for a fourth
season.[6] Nearly a year after the renewal, it was announced that the show
would be moving to Disney Channel for its fourth season.[7]

##
Plot[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Star_vs._the_Forces_of_Evil&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Plot")]

Main article: [List of Star vs. the Forces of Evil
characters](/wiki/List_of_Star_vs._the_Forces_of_Evil_characters "List of Star
vs. the Forces of Evil characters")

Star Butterfly is a [magical princess](/wiki/Magical_girl "Magical girl") from
the dimension of Mewni, and the heir to the royal throne of the Butterfly
Kingdom. As per tradition, she is given the family heirloom wand on her 14th
birthday. After she accidentally sets fire to the family castle, her parents
King and Queen Butterfly decide that a safer option is to send her to Earth as
a [foreign exchange student](/wiki/Foreign_exchange_student "Foreign exchange
student"), so she can continue her magic training there. She befriends Marco
Diaz and lives with his family while attending Echo Creek Academy. Going in a
series of misadventures using "dimensional scissors" that can open
[portals](/wiki/Portals_in_fiction "Portals in fiction"), Star and Marco must
deal with everyday school life while protecting Star's wand from falling into
the hands of Ludo, a villain from Mewni who commands a group of monsters.
Besides also dealing with her ex-boyfriend Tom, in Season 3, Star goes up
against more serious villains like Toffee and Miss Heinous while uncovering
the mystery behind her relative Eclipsa Butterfly.

## Background and
production[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Star_vs._the_Forces_of_Evil&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Background and production")]

Nefcy said she originally created Star as a girl who wanted to be a [magical
girl](/wiki/Magical_girl "Magical girl") like _[Sailor
Moon](/wiki/Sailor_Moon_\(character\) "Sailor Moon \(character\)")_ , and
Marco as a boy who was obsessed with _[Dragon Ball Z](/wiki/Dragon_Ball_Z
"Dragon Ball Z")_ and karate; they would be enemies instead of friends. In
this earlier version, Star did not have any actual magical powers; she instead
would approach and solve problems primarily through the force of her
determination alone.[8][9] Nefcy began pitching the show when she was in her
third year of college, when Cartoon Network was actively soliciting the
creation of pilots for prospective new shows.[10] Nefcy originally placed Star
in the fourth grade, reflecting on a time in her own childhood when she held a
self-described obsession with the animated series _[Sailor
Moon](/wiki/Sailor_Moon_\(anime\) "Sailor Moon \(anime\)")_. However, Nefcy
later adjusted the character's age to fourteen during the time she made her
series proposition to Disney.[10][8][11] An executive at that time made the
suggestion for Star to have actual magical powers. Nefcy worked this concept
into the show's current iteration, along with the idea of different dimensions
as show locations, the framing device of Star being a foreign exchange
student, and the plot aspects relating to Star being a princess and the
subsequent consequences of her royal birthright.[9] Nefcy said that the
overall concept has evolved over about six years.[11]

In addition to _[Sailor Moon](/wiki/Sailor_Moon_\(anime\) "Sailor Moon
\(anime\)")_ and _[Dragon Ball Z](/wiki/Dragon_Ball_Z "Dragon Ball Z")_ ,
Nefcy has said that she had heavy influence in her youth from the animated
Japanese shows _[Magic Knight Rayearth](/wiki/Magic_Knight_Rayearth "Magic
Knight Rayearth")_ , _[Revolutionary Girl
Utena](/wiki/Revolutionary_Girl_Utena "Revolutionary Girl Utena")_ and
_[Unico](/wiki/Unico "Unico")_ , the last of which featured a pink unicorn.
She also cited shows unrelated to Japanese animation such as _[Buffy the
Vampire Slayer](/wiki/Buffy_the_Vampire_Slayer "Buffy the Vampire Slayer")_
,[9] and was influenced by independent comic series such as _[Scott
Pilgrim](/wiki/Scott_Pilgrim "Scott Pilgrim")_ and _The Dungeon_.[11] With
regards to the development of more strong female characters, Nefcy said that
she "looked at TV over the years and I have had to go to Japan when I was
younger to find the cartoons that had the characters that I wanted to see. It
was always a question of 'Well, why isn't that on TV in the U.S.?'"[8]

One of the concepts she likes about the show is that it doesn't make high
school the most important experience for teenagers. She also likes that Star
does her own thing instead of being concerned about fitting in.[9] Nefcy did
not want the gimmick about keeping the magic powers a secret from others as
typical of magical girl shows, so she had the students already know about it
and Marco's parents as well. She also portrays Star as not really a superhero
as she does not specifically go after super-villains except when they attack
her, and that she doesn't really save people.[10] Nefcy said that the episodes
balance comedy and drama: "we really want our characters to feel like
teenagers and have them going through the normal emotions that teenagers go
through, but in this magical setting."[8]

Storyboarding and design are done in Los Angeles.[11] In describing the
process, Nefcy said that the show is storyboard-driven, with each episode
mapped out by the storyboard artists. The storyboarders also do the writing,
taking a two-page outline and turning it into a full script. A storyboard for
11 minutes would require about 2000 drawings to be done in a six-week
period.[12] After pre-production in the US, the first season animation was
done at [Mercury Filmworks](/wiki/Mercury_Filmworks "Mercury Filmworks") in
Ottawa, Canada. Mercury had also done _[Wander Over
Yonder](/wiki/Wander_Over_Yonder "Wander Over Yonder")_ and the _[Mickey
Mouse](/wiki/Mickey_Mouse_\(TV_series\) "Mickey Mouse \(TV series\)")_
series.[11] For the rest of first season, the animation was done in the
Philippines.[12] The second season was animated by Sugarcube and [Rough Draft
Studios](/wiki/Rough_Draft_Studios "Rough Draft Studios"), both located in
South Korea.[13][14]

The theme song was done by Brad Breeck, who also did _[Gravity
Falls](/wiki/Gravity_Falls "Gravity Falls")_ ' opening theme; Nefcy said:
"when we were listening to it we didn't know, because we just listened
[blind](/wiki/Blind_experiment "Blind experiment")". Brian Kim was chosen
among a group of about ten people as the show's composer.[10][15] Kim
describes the music for each dimension as having a different sound and
relating it to indie rock in Los Angeles.[16]

The show was initially scheduled to premiere on [Disney
Channel](/wiki/Disney_Channel "Disney Channel") after being greenlighted in
March 2013, for a premiere in the Fall of 2014, before being switched over to
Disney XD.[10][17] However, on February 23, 2018, it was announced that the
show would be moving to Disney Channel for its fourth season.[7]

## Promotion and
release[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Star_vs._the_Forces_of_Evil&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Promotion and release")]

The show's title sequence was promoted at [Comic-Con
2014](/wiki/San_Diego_Comic-Con_International "San Diego Comic-Con
International") six months prior to its scheduled broadcast premiere. As a
result, the footage was uploaded by fans to YouTube who then started
generating fan art and fan fiction.[11] The first episode premiered on Disney
Channel in January 2015. The positive reaction on social media prompted Disney
XD to order a second season of the series in February 2015, six weeks ahead of
its launch of the series on Disney XD in March.[18] Disney sitcom actors
[Olivia Holt](/wiki/Olivia_Holt "Olivia Holt") and [Kelli
Berglund](/wiki/Kelli_Berglund "Kelli Berglund") participated in promoting the
series the weeks before its Disney XD premiere, with Holt dressing up as
Star.[19][20]

The second season premiered on July 11, 2016,[21] The show's third season was
ordered ahead in March 2016.[22] It premiered on July 15, 2017 with a two-hour
long television movie entitled "The Battle for Mewni" and consisted of the
first four episodes.[23][24] A live chat featuring Star and Marco was aired on
Disney XD on July 17.[25] The remaining third-season episodes starting airing
on November 6, 2017.[26][27] A fourth season was also ordered ahead of the
third season premiere.[6]

###
International[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Star_vs._the_Forces_of_Evil&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: International")]

_Star vs. the Forces of Evil_ premiered in Canada on [the DHX-owned Disney
XD](/wiki/Family_Chrgd "Family Chrgd") on April 6, 2015,[28] and was later
moved to [the Corus-owned Disney XD](/wiki/Disney_XD_\(Canada\) "Disney XD
\(Canada\)") on December 1.[29] The series premiered on Disney XD channels in
the [United Kingdom and Ireland](/wiki/Disney_XD_\(UK_and_Ireland\) "Disney XD
\(UK and Ireland\)") on April 16, 2015,[30][_[better source
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:NOTRS "Wikipedia:NOTRS")_] in
[Australia](/wiki/Disney_XD_\(Australia\) "Disney XD \(Australia\)") on August
3,[31] and in the [Middle East and Africa](/wiki/Disney_XD_\(Africa\) "Disney
XD \(Africa\)") on October 5.[32] It also premiered on November 8 on [Disney
Channel](/wiki/Disney_Channel_\(Asia\) "Disney Channel \(Asia\)") in Southeast
Asia.[33][34] The series premiered on March 6, 2016, as _Star Butterfly_ in
French on [Disney La Chaîne](/wiki/Disney_La_Cha%C3%AEne "Disney La Chaîne")
in Canada.[35] The show premiered on November 2 on [Disney
XD](/wiki/Disney_XD_\(Italy\) "Disney XD \(Italy\)") in Italy, and on [Disney
Channel](/wiki/Disney_Channel_\(Italy\) "Disney Channel \(Italy\)") on
November 2, 2016.[36]

##
Reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Star_vs._the_Forces_of_Evil&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Reception")]

_Star vs. the Forces of Evil_ has received positive reviews by critics.

Kevin Johnson of _[The A.V. Club](/wiki/The_A.V._Club "The A.V. Club")_ gave
the pilot episode a B+, saying that the show was something children could have
a lot of fun with, noting how the show follows current trends in western
animation "towards large-eyed characters and quirky visual trends". Johnson
stated that _Star vs. the Forces of Evil_ "excels on wild, silly, and clever
set-pieces to bring the laughs and action", but expected that adult viewers
won't get much out of it.[37] Furthermore, the premiere of _Star vs. the
Forces of Evil_ became the most-watched animated series debut in Disney XD’s
history.[4] Following the end of the second season, Disney XD announced it had
ordered a fourth season of the show, and that in 2016, _Star_ and another
animated show _[Milo Murphy's Law](/wiki/Milo_Murphy%27s_Law "Milo Murphy's
Law")_ had reached over 100 million consumer views combined across its media
platforms.[6]

In reviewing episodes from the first season, Marcy Cook of _[The Mary
Sue](/wiki/The_Mary_Sue "The Mary Sue")_ described the show as a blend of
others such as _[Invader Zim](/wiki/Invader_Zim "Invader Zim")_ and a
sanitized _[Ren& Stimpy](/wiki/Ren_%26_Stimpy "Ren & Stimpy")_, with great
appeal to tween and teen girls as well some laugh out loud moments for adults.
She said, "[I]t's really cool to see a girl who is into cuteness and rainbows
also kick-ass and enjoy it". Cook was bothered by the short episodes that made
the plot seem rushed or underdeveloped. Cook was bugged by Marco's
[retconned](/wiki/Retcon "Retcon") personality from the pilot episode where he
was a safety conscious kid to the series where he was a martial arts fight
seeker.[38] Caitlin Donovan of entertainment website Epicstream listed it
among her top 10 animated series of 2015. She found the first few episodes to
be "a little rough for me, like the show was trying too hard to be funny and
weird", but that the show got better with character development and
relationship building, with "a really dramatic, high-tension finale to the
first season".[39]

### Awards and
nominations[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Star_vs._the_Forces_of_Evil&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Awards and nominations")]

The episode "Party with a Pony" was showcased in the [Annecy International
Animated Film Festival](/wiki/Annecy_International_Animated_Film_Festival
"Annecy International Animated Film Festival") in June 2015.[40][41]

Year  | Award  | Category  | Nominee  | Result  | Ref

## Other
media[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Star_vs._the_Forces_of_Evil&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Other media")]

A comic book series titled _Deep Trouble_ was written by storyboarder Zach
Marcus and illustrated by character designer Devin Taylor, both of whom are
part of the _Star_ crew. They have been released monthly by Joe Books starting
in September 2016.[43][44] A _Cinestory_ comic was also developed and
released.[45]

The book _Star and Marco 's Guide to Mastering Every Dimension_, authored by
[Amber Benson](/wiki/Amber_Benson "Amber Benson") and supervising producer
Dominic Bisignano, was released on March 7, 2017.[46][47]
